 First of all, I`m not norweigan so I don`t have any real experience with the norweigan economic system. But here is my explanations and points:
 
 Norway is incredibly rich. But it chooses not to spend this wealth for two reasons: 1. Unlike most countries on this planet, Norway has realized that their main source of wealth, their oil deposits are finite. and 2: Because of their massive national income from oil, Norway are afraid of setting of an inflation spiral that would undercut their international competativity. With prices allready higher than their neighbouring countries, Norway`s government is wary of their spending (even though they could easily afford it).
 
 With this in mind, the Norweigan government saves a tremendous amount of their GDP in foreign funds and currencies. Compare this to most countries high national debts and rampant budget decifits and you`ll understand why norweigans, one of the wealthiest people in the world, doesn`t drive around in the newest model of sportscars.
 
 Another aspect is also the difference between european and american relation or preferences towards working and leisure time. Just like most european countries, norweigans on average work far less than the average american. Naturally this will be reflected in material standards (such as GDP and access to new shiny toys).
 
 As for the reference to the "Swedish research organization, Timbro", this should be taken with a pinch of salt. The research organisation is nothing more than a political think-tank bent on destroying the Swedish and european wellfare state. It`s a joke to call it a research organisation... I actually think we discussed the so-called study on this board. I have read it numerous times and is full of deceptive and even fraudulent errors, such as comparing american households with Swedish household without even mentioning that US households are two person households (families) where as hushåll in Sweden are generally one person households.
 
 I would also like to point out that Norway constantly tops every attempt to compare material or immaterial wellfare of countries. I certainly would say that Norway is, if not the richest country, at least among the richest countries in the world. And with a populace with the highest wellfare.

 I did my own investigation. Pretty good shape at 22% of GDP. Here is the CIA take on Norway. 
 =====================
 The Norwegian economy is a prosperous bastion of welfare capitalism, featuring a combination of free market activity and government intervention. The government controls key areas, such as the vital petroleum sector (through large-scale state enterprises). The country is richly endowed with natural resources - petroleum, hydropower, fish, forests, and minerals - and is highly dependent on its oil production and international oil prices, with oil and gas accounting for one-third of exports. Only Saudi Arabia and Russia export more oil than Norway. Norway opted to stay out of the EU during a referendum in November 1994. The government has moved ahead with privatization. With arguably the highest quality of life worldwide, Norwegians still worry about that time in the next two decades when the oil and gas begin to run out. Accordingly, Norway has been saving its oil-boosted budget surpluses in a Government Petroleum Fund, which is invested abroad and now is valued at more than $43 billion. GDP growth was a lackluster 1% in 2002 and 0.5% in 2003 against the background of a faltering European economy.
 ===================================
 
 BTW, the U.S. public debt is 62.4% of GDP. By contrast, Japan is 154.6% of GDP. Germany is 64.2% and France is 68.8% and Sweden is 51.8% (pretty good). Netherlands is 54.1%.
